nodes.bodyText: Is the check this != Object.class necessary?

I believe this is referring to the javadoc line:

If C is a class other than Object, then include the result of invoking this algorithm recursively on the superclass of C.

Though in practice I think it may not be needed. @ChengJin01 do you have any insights to this from your testing?

It looks like this check is also done https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/8bf4dc691e37ba4c7cfc0ebe85f78e8c12736625/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/Class.java#L1594 so its not necessary to do it twice.
@theresa-m, Object.class should be excluded in the search of superclass in any case. Please modify accordingly if any duplicate and verify the update with all tests.
It appears this method is going to repeat getMethodImpl(name, parameterTypes, strSig) regardless of other conditions which is not desirable.
Yes good catch. I can rearrange that to prevent duplicate calls.
This method might return null while initial result isn't, this doesn't seem right.
Any particular reason to create new HashSet() without actual usage after the following method call?
Similar comment about this interfaceSet as well.

getMethods() is going to be invoked for the superclasses from the top to the bottom, and the later invocations include the results of previous calls which seems an overkill.
can we modify getMethodImpl(name, parameterTypes, strSig) to introduce a startingPoint, particularly for the case that the method found is declared by an interface class?

I agree that it is overkill.
I think it would still be useful to take advantage of the getMethods helper functions for the sake of not duplicating code, and combining the logic was helpful in that I was able to improve correctness of getMethod and getMethods at the same time. I can limit the superclasses searches for this particular case.

Not against the idea. getMethods() just is a heavyweight api, can getMethodImpl & getDeclaredMethodImpl be used for the superclasses from the top to the bottom instead?

improve correctness of getMethod and getMethods at the same time

getMethod() calls getMethodHelper() which is being fixed by this PR.
does getMethods() miss any method?

Not against the idea. getMethods() just is a heavyweight api, can getMethodImpl & getDeclaredMethodImpl be used for the superclasses from the top to the bottom instead?

I think your idea of adding a startingPoint type variable to getMethodImpl would be a good solution as well.
edit: Although I'm not sure it would be a simple native change since each call to getMethodImpl uses the entire interface list to determine which interface is the most valid match.


improve correctness of getMethod and getMethods at the same time

getMethod() calls getMethodHelper() which is being fixed by this PR.
does getMethods() miss any method?

There is one case for getMethods being fixed here as well that was uncovered by one of the tests from #7623. Maybe that will explain more how that line of thinking came about too :) I will make that more obvious in the issue description.

@JasonFengJ9  I made some updates to this approach to tighten things up. getMostSpecificMethodFromAllInterfacesOfCurrentClass will now call getMethodSet directly, and then only search for interfaces and not classes. Let me know what you think.

is there a chance that infoCache could be confused by localInterfacesOnly since the key is always this class?
I didn't go thorough all use cases, but just wondering if such possibility has been considered.
I made some modifications so it is more clear which this is being used by getMethodSet.

infoCache seems not for late use after current getMethodHelper() call hence won't help much performance.
In that case, getInterfaces() is a better choice.
@theresa-m is there a PR update since last comment?

In my opinion getMethodSet is okay. getInterfaces could be used but getMethodSet is already getting interfaces recursively calling getInterfaces. From a maintainability standpoint I think it will be advantageous to maintain one spot for the override logic in update: https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/1ed4919d1a2f9eb58ce7bd4facc99bcb76068bf9/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/Class.java#L3890
An alternative solution as discussed offline would be to move more of this logic into native code however this would require quite a bit of work.
